thread.title: Household spending revival at risk as consumers lose confidence
thread.title_full: Household spending revival at risk as consumers lose confidence | afr.com

author: Jens Meyer
title: Household spending revival at risk as consumers lose confidence
text:
An investor looks at a screens showing stock information at a brokerage house in Shanghai. Reuters Share on twitter by Jens Meyer The volatility in the Chinese stock market and the Greek debt drama appear to have driven consumer confidence sharply lower.
Consumer confidence fell 3.6 per cent last week, following a 4.6 per cent fall in the previous week, according to the latest ANZ/Roy Morgan weekly survey.
"The rapid turnaround in sentiment highlights the sensitivity of consumers towards both domestic and global conditions," says ANZ chief economist Warren Hogan.
"Chinese stock market volatility and current negotiations surrounding Greece have dominated the news-flow over the past two weeks and spilled over into the local sharemarket," he says.
The latest drop more than reverses the positive reaction to the May rate cut and budget in just two weeks. Confidence is now at the lowest level in 12 months, ANZ says.
"Despite the stabilisation in the unemployment rate, ongoing weakness in consumer confidence would present a risk to the outlook for household spending," Mr Hogan says.
Aus consumers more worried about the medium term economic outlook than during the GFC #ausecon #auspol pic.twitter.com/j5oiEwZn2b
â€” Warren Hogan (@anz_warrenhogan) July 14, 2015
